title: Thales of Miletus
summary: The dawn of naturalistic explanation.
description: Often considered the first philosopher, Thales sought to explain the world through natural phenomena, positing water as the single underlying substance ('arche').

miniEvents.title: Anaximander's 'Apeiron'
miniEvents.summary: Thales's student proposes an indefinite, boundless substance as the origin of all things.

miniEvents.title: Anaximenes's 'Aer'
miniEvents.summary: Suggests 'aer' (air) is the primary substance, explaining matter via condensation and rarefaction.

quotes.text: The most difficult thing in life is to know yourself.
Water is the principle of all things.

title: Socrates
summary: The unexamined life is not worth living.
description: Socrates shifted philosophy's focus to ethics and self-examination, using his Socratic method of questioning to reveal ignorance and pursue truth.

miniEvents.title: The Oracle at Delphi
miniEvents.summary: The Oracle's famous declaration spurred his mission to question the supposed wisdom of others.

miniEvents.title: Trial and Execution
miniEvents.summary: His methods led to his trial for corrupting the youth, where he chose death over exile.

quotes.text: The unexamined life is not worth living.
I know that I know nothing.
True wisdom comes to each of us when we realize how little we understand about life, ourselves, and the world around us.

title: Plato Founds the Academy
summary: The world of ideal Forms is the true reality.
description: Plato's Theory of Forms posits a higher reality of perfect concepts, of which our world is a mere shadow. His Academy was the first institution of higher learning in the West.

miniEvents.title: Writing 'The Republic'
miniEvents.summary: Plato outlines his vision of a just state ruled by philosopher-kings and the Allegory of the Cave.

miniEvents.title: The 'Symposium'
miniEvents.summary: A dialogue exploring the nature of love, climbing from carnal desire to abstract beauty.

quotes.text: Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle.
The measure of a man is what he does with power.
Opinion is the medium between knowledge and ignorance.

title: Aristotle & The Lyceum
summary: Systematizing logic and the natural world.
description: A student of Plato, Aristotle focused on the empirical world, developing formal logic and systematically studying biology, ethics, and politics.

miniEvents.title: Nicomachean Ethics
miniEvents.summary: Aristotle's inquiry into 'eudaimonia' (human flourishing) and virtue through the 'golden mean'.

miniEvents.title: Prior Analytics
miniEvents.summary: The invention of the syllogism, a form of deductive reasoning that founded logic for centuries.

quotes.text: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
Man is by nature a political animal.
Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.

title: Pythagoras
summary: All is number.
description: Pythagoras founded a philosophical and religious movement that saw mathematics as the key to understanding reality, believing numbers underlie all natural phenomena.

quotes.text: There is geometry in the humming of the strings, there is music in the spacing of the spheres.
Number is the ruler of forms and ideas.

title: Heraclitus
summary: Everything flows; you cannot step into the same river twice.
description: Heraclitus proposed that change is the fundamental nature of the universe, with fire as the primary element and the Logos as the underlying order of all things.

quotes.text: No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it is not the same river and he is not the same man.
The only thing that is constant is change.

title: Epicurus
summary: Pleasure is the highest good.
description: Epicurus founded a school advocating a life of moderate pleasure, friendship, and freedom from fear, including fear of the gods and death.

miniEvents.title: The Garden
miniEvents.summary: Epicurus's school in Athens, open to all including women and slaves, emphasizing communal philosophical living.

quotes.text: Death does not concern us, because as long as we exist, death is not here. And when it does come, we no longer exist.
Do not spoil what you have by desiring what you have not.

title: Zeno of Citium
summary: Virtue is the only true good.
description: Zeno founded Stoicism, teaching that virtue aligned with reason and nature is the path to tranquility, and that external events are beyond our control.

quotes.text: Man conquers the world by conquering himself.
We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen more than we say.
quotes.source: Attributed to Zeno of Citium by Diogenes Laertius

title: Augustine of Hippo
summary: Bridging Christian theology with Platonic philosophy.
description: Augustine's work, such as 'Confessions' and 'City of God', profoundly shaped Western Christianity and explored concepts of free will, divine grace, and original sin.

miniEvents.title: Doctrine of Original Sin
miniEvents.summary: His formulation of the concept that humanity is inherently flawed from the sin of Adam.

miniEvents.title: Just War Theory
miniEvents.summary: Early articulations of the conditions under which war could be morally justifiable.

quotes.text: The world is a book and those who do not travel read only one page.
Faith is to believe what you do not see; the reward of this faith is to see what you believe.
Our hearts are restless until they rest in Thee.

title: Avicenna (Ibn Sina)
summary: Synthesizing Islamic theology and Aristotelianism.
description: A Persian polymath, Avicenna's 'The Canon of Medicine' was a standard medical text for centuries, and his philosophical works integrated Aristotle's ideas into the Islamic world.

miniEvents.title: The Floating Man
miniEvents.summary: A thought experiment to demonstrate the existence of the soul and self-awareness, independent of sensory experience.

miniEvents.title: Proof of the Truthful
miniEvents.summary: An ontological argument for the existence of God as a 'necessary existent'.

quotes.text: The knowledge of anything, since all things have causes, is not acquired or complete unless it is known by its causes.
Now it is established in the sciences that no knowledge is acquired save through the study of its causes and beginnings.

title: Thomas Aquinas
summary: The apex of scholasticism.
description: In his 'Summa Theologica', Aquinas methodically blended Aristotelian philosophy with Christian doctrine, creating a comprehensive system of thought that became foundational for the Catholic Church.

miniEvents.title: The Five Ways
miniEvents.summary: His five logical arguments for the existence of God, including the arguments from motion and causation.

miniEvents.title: Natural Law
miniEvents.summary: His theory that human reason can discern universal moral principles inherent in nature.

quotes.text: To one who has faith, no explanation is necessary. To one without faith, no explanation is possible.
The things that we love tell us what we are.
There is nothing on this earth more to be prized than true friendship.

title: Boethius
summary: The consolation of philosophy in the face of fate.
description: Boethius wrote 'The Consolation of Philosophy' while awaiting execution, exploring how reason and philosophy can provide comfort against misfortune.

quotes.text: In every adversity of fortune, to have been happy is the most unhappy kind of misfortune.
Nothing is miserable unless you think it so; and on the other hand, nothing brings happiness unless you are content with it.

title: Al-Farabi
summary: The Second Teacher, after Aristotle.
description: Al-Farabi sought to harmonize Plato and Aristotle, contributing major works on logic, political philosophy, and the classification of sciences in the Islamic Golden Age.

quotes.text: The idea of the virtuous city is that community where people aim through association at the highest happiness.
Philosophy first emerged in the Chaldean nation, among the people of Iraq.
quotes.source: Al-Farabi, On the Appearance of Philosophy

title: Maimonides
summary: Reconciling Jewish theology with Aristotelian philosophy.
description: Maimonides wrote 'The Guide for the Perplexed', a landmark work reconciling faith and reason within the Jewish intellectual tradition.

quotes.text: Teach thy tongue to say I do not know, and thou shalt progress.
Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.

title: William of Ockham
summary: Entities should not be multiplied without necessity.
description: William of Ockham championed nominalism and is best known for Ockham's Razor, the principle of parsimony that favors simpler explanations over complex ones.

miniEvents.title: Ockham's Razor
miniEvents.summary: The methodological principle that the simplest explanation is usually the best, deeply influential in science and philosophy.

quotes.text: Entities should not be multiplied without necessity.
quotes.source: Attributed to William of Ockham (Ockham's Razor)

quotes.text: It is vain to do with more what can be done with fewer.

title: Rene Descartes
summary: Cogito, ergo sum: I think, therefore I am.
description: Descartes's method of radical doubt established a foundation for modern philosophy, emphasizing reason as the primary source of knowledge.

miniEvents.title: 'Discourse on the Method'
miniEvents.summary: Publication of his seminal work, introducing his method and the famous 'Cogito' as an indubitable truth.

miniEvents.title: Cartesian Dualism
miniEvents.summary: The formal separation of the immaterial mind from the material body, setting the stage for debate.

quotes.text: I think, therefore I am.
Doubt is the origin of wisdom.
It is not enough to have a good mind; the main thing is to use it well.

title: John Locke
summary: The father of Liberalism and the Tabula Rasa.
description: Locke's theories on government by consent and natural rights were pivotal for the American Revolution. He argued the mind is a 'blank slate' at birth, shaped by experience.

miniEvents.title: 'Two Treatises of Government'
miniEvents.summary: A foundational text for liberal democracy, arguing against the divine right of kings.

miniEvents.title: Tabula Rasa
miniEvents.summary: His theory of the 'blank slate' mind, a cornerstone of empiricism.

quotes.text: No man's knowledge here can go beyond his experience.
quotes.source: Locke, An Essay Concerning Human Understanding

quotes.text: New opinions are always suspected, and usually opposed, without any other reason but because they are not already common.
quotes.source: Locke, An Essay Concerning Human Understanding

quotes.text: The end of law is not to abolish or restrain, but to preserve and enlarge freedom.

title: Immanuel Kant
summary: Synthesizing rationalism and empiricism.
description: Kant's 'Critique of Pure Reason' revolutionized philosophy, arguing that the mind actively structures our experience of reality.

miniEvents.title: The Copernican Revolution
miniEvents.summary: Kant's proposal that objects conform to our knowledge, rather than our knowledge to objects.

miniEvents.title: 'What is Enlightenment?'
miniEvents.summary: An influential essay arguing for the use of one's own reason and courage to think for oneself ('Sapere aude').

quotes.text: Act only according to that maxim whereby you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law.
quotes.source: Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals

quotes.text: Dare to know! Have the courage to use your own understanding.
Two things fill the mind with ever new and increasing admiration and awe: the starry heavens above me and the moral law within me.

title: Baruch Spinoza
summary: God and Nature are one and the same.
description: Spinoza's 'Ethics' presented a radical pantheistic vision where God and the universe are identical, challenging traditional religious thought with rigorous geometric reasoning.

quotes.text: Peace is not an absence of war, it is a virtue, a state of mind, a disposition for benevolence, confidence, justice.
The highest activity a human being can attain is learning for understanding, because to understand is to be free.

title: David Hume
summary: Reason is the slave of the passions.
description: Hume's radical empiricism questioned causation, the self, and induction, arguing that our beliefs are grounded in habit and custom rather than rational proof.

miniEvents.title: The Problem of Induction
miniEvents.summary: Hume's argument that we cannot rationally justify the assumption that the future will resemble the past.

quotes.text: Reason is, and ought only to be the slave of the passions.
quotes.source: Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature

quotes.text: A wise man proportions his belief to the evidence.
quotes.source: Hume, An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding

quotes.text: Custom is the great guide of human life.
quotes.source: Hume, An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding

title: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
summary: Man is born free, and everywhere he is in chains.
description: Rousseau argued that civilization corrupts humanity's natural goodness, and that legitimate political authority rests on a social contract among citizens.

quotes.text: Man is born free, and everywhere he is in chains.
I prefer liberty with danger than peace with slavery.

title: Voltaire
summary: Champion of civil liberties and freedom of expression.
description: Voltaire was a fierce advocate of reason, religious tolerance, and separation of church and state, using satire and wit to challenge established authority.

quotes.text: Judge a man by his questions rather than by his answers.
Those who can make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities.
We must cultivate our garden.

title: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
summary: We live in the best of all possible worlds.
description: Leibniz was a polymath who developed calculus independently of Newton, proposed the theory of monads, and argued that God created the best possible world through the principle of sufficient reason.

miniEvents.title: Monadology
miniEvents.summary: His theory that reality consists of simple, indivisible substances called monads, each reflecting the entire universe.

quotes.text: This is the best of all possible worlds.
Nothing is without reason.
There are two kinds of truths: truths of reasoning and truths of fact.

title: George Berkeley
summary: To be is to be perceived.
description: Berkeley's idealism argued that material objects exist only as perceptions in minds. He famously questioned whether a tree falling in an empty forest makes a sound.

quotes.text: To be is to be perceived.
quotes.source: Berkeley, A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge

quotes.text: Truth is the cry of all, but the game of few.

title: G.W.F. Hegel
summary: History as the progression of Spirit (Geist).
description: Hegel developed a comprehensive system of German Idealism, viewing history as a rational process of dialectical progression towards absolute knowledge.

miniEvents.title: 'Phenomenology of Spirit'
miniEvents.summary: Traces the evolution of consciousness from sense-perception to absolute knowledge.

miniEvents.title: Master-Slave Dialectic
miniEvents.summary: A famous allegory describing the development of self-consciousness through a struggle for recognition.

quotes.text: The real is rational and the rational is real.
quotes.source: Hegel, Elements of the Philosophy of Right

quotes.text: The owl of Minerva spreads its wings only with the falling of the dusk.
quotes.source: Hegel, Elements of the Philosophy of Right

quotes.text: We learn from history that we do not learn from history.

title: Friedrich Nietzsche
summary: The death of God and the will to power.
description: Nietzsche was a fierce critic of traditional morality and religion, proposing the concepts of the Ubermensch and eternal recurrence.

miniEvents.title: 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra'
miniEvents.summary: A philosophical novel introducing the concepts of the Ubermensch (Overman) and eternal recurrence.

miniEvents.title: Master-Slave Morality
miniEvents.summary: A central theme critiquing Judeo-Christian ethics as a 'slave revolt' in morality.

quotes.text: He who has a why to live for can bear almost any how.
God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him.
Without music, life would be a mistake.

title: Arthur Schopenhauer
summary: The world as will and representation.
description: Schopenhauer argued that reality is driven by a blind, purposeless force called the Will, and that suffering is an inherent part of existence that can only be alleviated through aesthetic contemplation and asceticism.

quotes.text: All truth passes through three stages. First, it is ridiculed. Second, it is violently opposed. Third, it is accepted as being self-evident.
Talent hits a target no one else can hit; genius hits a target no one else can see.
quotes.source: Schopenhauer, The World as Will and Representation

title: Soren Kierkegaard
summary: The father of existentialism.
description: Kierkegaard emphasized the importance of individual subjective experience, the leap of faith, and the anxiety of freedom, laying the groundwork for existentialist philosophy.

miniEvents.title: Either/Or
miniEvents.summary: A work presenting contrasting aesthetic and ethical modes of life as fundamental existential choices.

quotes.text: Life can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards.
Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom.
The most common form of despair is not being who you are.

title: Karl Marx
summary: Philosophers have only interpreted the world; the point is to change it.
description: Marx developed historical materialism and critiqued capitalism, arguing that class struggle drives historical change and that economic conditions shape all of society.

miniEvents.title: The Communist Manifesto
miniEvents.summary: A political pamphlet calling for the workers of the world to unite and overthrow the bourgeoisie.

quotes.text: The philosophers have only interpreted the world, in various ways; the point is to change it.
The history of all hitherto existing society is the history of class struggles.
quotes.source: Marx and Engels, The Communist Manifesto

quotes.text: Religion is the opium of the people.
quotes.source: Marx, Critique of Hegel's Philosophy of Right

title: John Stuart Mill
summary: The greatest happiness of the greatest number.
description: Mill refined utilitarian philosophy, championed individual liberty, and advocated for women's rights, becoming one of the most influential liberal thinkers.

quotes.text: It is better to be a human being dissatisfied than a pig satisfied; better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied.
Over himself, over his own body and mind, the individual is sovereign.
The only freedom which deserves the name is that of pursuing our own good in our own way.

title: Parmenides
summary: What is, is; what is not, is not.
description: Parmenides argued that reality is one, unchanging, and eternal. Change and plurality are mere illusions. His logical arguments about being profoundly influenced metaphysics.

quotes.text: What is, is; what is not, is not.
For never shall this be proved, that things that are not are.

title: Democritus
summary: Nothing exists except atoms and empty space.
description: Democritus developed atomic theory, proposing that all matter consists of indivisible particles called atoms moving through void. This materialist view anticipated modern physics.

quotes.text: Nothing exists except atoms and empty space; everything else is opinion.
Happiness resides not in possessions, and not in gold; happiness dwells in the soul.

title: Marcus Aurelius
summary: The philosopher emperor.
description: Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius authored 'Meditations', a series of personal writings embodying Stoic philosophy. His reflections on duty, mortality, and inner peace remain influential.

miniEvents.title: Meditations
miniEvents.summary: Personal writings offering practical Stoic wisdom on maintaining virtue amid the pressures of ruling an empire.

quotes.text: You have power over your mind, not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
Waste no more time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.

title: Ludwig Wittgenstein
summary: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.
description: Wittgenstein's work transformed analytic philosophy, first with his picture theory of meaning and later with his concept of language-games.

miniEvents.title: 'Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus'
miniEvents.summary: His early work arguing that language can only represent the world, and what cannot be said must be passed over in silence.

miniEvents.title: 'Philosophical Investigations'
miniEvents.summary: His posthumous work rejecting many of his earlier ideas, introducing the concept of language as a tool with many uses.

quotes.text: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.
Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.
A serious and good philosophical work could be written consisting entirely of jokes.

title: Simone de Beauvoir
summary: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.
description: De Beauvoir's 'The Second Sex' is a foundational text of second-wave feminism, analyzing the social construction of gender.

miniEvents.title: The Other
miniEvents.summary: Her analysis of how man is positioned as the default subject, while woman is constructed as the 'Other'.

miniEvents.title: Ethics of Ambiguity
miniEvents.summary: An exploration of existentialist ethics, arguing that human freedom is the ultimate good.

quotes.text: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.
Change your life today. Don't gamble on the future, act now, without delay.
I am too intelligent, too demanding, and too resourceful for anyone to be able to take charge of me entirely.
quotes.source: Beauvoir, Memoirs of a Dutiful Daughter

title: Martin Heidegger
summary: The question of Being.
description: Heidegger's 'Being and Time' explored the meaning of existence through the concept of Dasein (being-there), profoundly influencing phenomenology and existentialism.

miniEvents.title: Being and Time
miniEvents.summary: A groundbreaking work analyzing human existence through temporality, authenticity, and being-toward-death.

quotes.text: The most thought-provoking thing in our thought-provoking time is that we are still not thinking.
Language is the house of Being.
Every man is born as many men and dies as a single one.

title: Jean-Paul Sartre
summary: Existence precedes essence.
description: Sartre's existentialism holds that humans are condemned to be free, with no predetermined nature or purpose, and must create meaning through their choices and actions.

quotes.text: Existence precedes essence.
Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does.
Hell is other people.

title: Albert Camus
summary: One must imagine Sisyphus happy.
description: Camus explored the absurdity of human existence, arguing that life's lack of inherent meaning should be met with revolt, freedom, and passionate engagement rather than despair.

quotes.text: One must imagine Sisyphus happy.
In the depth of winter, I finally learned that within me there lay an invincible summer.
The only way to deal with an unfree world is to become so absolutely free that your very existence is an act of rebellion.

title: Michel Foucault
summary: Knowledge is power.
description: Foucault examined how power structures shape knowledge, institutions, and social norms, challenging the idea that truth exists independently of the systems that produce it.

miniEvents.title: Discipline and Punish
miniEvents.summary: An analysis of how modern institutions use surveillance and discipline to control individuals.

quotes.text: Where there is power, there is resistance.
Knowledge is not made for understanding; it is made for cutting.
People know what they do; frequently they know why they do what they do; but what they don't know is what what they do does.
quotes.source: Attributed to Foucault by Gilles Deleuze

title: William James
summary: The father of American psychology and pragmatism.
description: James pioneered pragmatism, arguing that the truth of an idea is measured by its practical consequences. His work bridged philosophy and psychology.

miniEvents.title: The Principles of Psychology
miniEvents.summary: A groundbreaking text that established psychology as a distinct scientific discipline.

quotes.text: Act as if what you do makes a difference. It does.
The greatest discovery of my generation is that a human being can alter his life by altering his attitudes.
A great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.

title: Charles Sanders Peirce
summary: The founder of pragmatism and semiotics.
description: Peirce developed pragmatism as a method for clarifying ideas through their practical effects, and pioneered semiotics, the study of signs and symbols.

quotes.text: Consider what effects, that might conceivably have practical bearings, we conceive the object of our conception to have. Then, our conception of these effects is the whole of our conception of the object.
quotes.source: Peirce, How to Make Our Ideas Clear

quotes.text: The opinion which is fated to be ultimately agreed to by all who investigate, is what we mean by the truth.
quotes.source: Peirce, How to Make Our Ideas Clear

title: Hannah Arendt
summary: The banality of evil.
description: Arendt examined totalitarianism, the nature of power, and political action. Her report on the Eichmann trial introduced the concept of the banality of evil.

miniEvents.title: The Human Condition
miniEvents.summary: An exploration of vita activa—labor, work, and action—and what it means to live a fully human life.

quotes.text: The sad truth is that most evil is done by people who never make up their minds to be good or evil.
quotes.source: Arendt, The Life of the Mind

quotes.text: Forgiveness is the key to action and freedom.
The most radical revolutionary will become a conservative the day after the revolution.

title: John Rawls
summary: Justice as fairness.
description: Rawls revitalized political philosophy with 'A Theory of Justice', arguing for principles of justice that rational people would choose behind a 'veil of ignorance'.

miniEvents.title: The Veil of Ignorance
miniEvents.summary: A thought experiment where people choose principles of justice without knowing their place in society.

quotes.text: Justice is the first virtue of social institutions, as truth is of systems of thought.
Injustice, then, is simply inequalities that are not to the benefit of all.

title: Jacques Derrida
summary: There is nothing outside the text.
description: Derrida founded deconstruction, a method of critical analysis that reveals hidden assumptions and contradictions in texts and ideas.

miniEvents.title: Of Grammatology
miniEvents.summary: A seminal work challenging Western philosophy's privileging of speech over writing.

quotes.text: There is nothing outside the text.
To pretend, I actually do the thing: I have therefore only pretended to pretend.
Every other is wholly other.
